item.title: Hong Kong Protest Live Updates: Police Disperse Protesters Outside Legislative Building
item.description: Protesters had mostly cleared out of the Legislative Council building after 3 hours of occupation. Then a cordon of riot police used tear gas and charged to scatter the crowd.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: On Hong Kong Handover Anniversary, Many Fear Loss of Freedoms
item.description: ‘One country, two systems’ was Beijing’s pledge when it took back a former British colony. But concerns over civil liberties are mounting.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: July 1997: Handover.

item.title: Why Many in China Oppose Hong Kong’s Protests
item.description: It goes beyond propaganda.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A democracy rally in Hong Kong last week.

item.title: Iran Breaches Critical Limit on Nuclear Fuel Under 2015 Deal
item.description: The violation does not by itself give the country the material for a nuclear weapon, but it signals that Tehran may be willing to abandon the pact’s limits.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Iranian Presidency Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran in 2018. He said this year that he intended to walk away from the nuclear deal’s restrictions.

item.title: In New Talks, U.S. May Settle for a Nuclear Freeze by North Korea
item.description: The idea taking shape inside the Trump administration would amount to negotiating a nuclear freeze that essentially enshrines the status quo, tacitly accepting the North as a nuclear power.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, on the North Korean side of the Demilitarized Zone on Sunday.

item.title: Ivanka Trump Tests Her Diplomatic Chops and Riles a Legion of Critics
item.description: President Trump’s elder daughter used a G20 summit and then the Demilitarized Zone to test her role as budding stateswoman for the administration.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump, the president’s elder daughter and senior adviser, at the Demilitarized Zone in South Korea on Sunday.

item.title: Bombing Kills Dozens and Hurts Schoolchildren as Taliban Talks Resume
item.description: While negotiators press toward a deal to withdraw U.S. troops, the Taliban set off bombs that wrecked a museum, TV station and a school in Kabul, Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Fatima Faizi, Rod Nordland and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Smoke billowing after a bombing in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Monday.

item.title: Alabamians Defend Arrest of Woman Whose Fetus Died in Shooting
item.description: The indictment of a woman in the shooting death of her fetus has sparked outrage across the country. But in Alabama, many people consider it just.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:description: An undated photo of Marshae Jones, provided by her family.

item.title: Consumers Are Spending. Businesses Aren’t. Who’s Right About the Future?
item.description: Forecasting is tricky when important economic indicators are pointing in different directions.
item.dc:creator: Neil Irwin
item.media:description: American consumption spending keeps showing healthy growth.

item.title: S&P and Dow Follow Global Markets Higher, as Investors Take Heart in Trade Thaw
item.description: Markets took heart in the resumption of negotiations between Washington and Beijing. Still, many doubt the two sides can reach a deal anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Matt Phillips

item.title: Kamala Harris and Classmates Were Bused Across Berkeley. The Experience Changed Them.
item.description: Fellow Berkeley public school students remember the early days of the integration effort: “We were all just kids trying to figure it out on our own.”
item.dc:creator: Nellie Bowles
item.media:description: Students boarded a school bus in Berkeley, Calif., in 1970. Students, including a young Kamala Harris, were bused to different neighborhoods in an effort to racially integrate the city’s schools.

item.title: North Korea, Hong Kong, N.B.A.: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Fewer Cars on 14th Street? Not Just Yet
item.description: Monday: A judge has halted New York's plan to turn the busy crosstown route into a transit corridor mainly for buses, trucks and emergency vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah

item.title: Inside the Migrant Detention Center in Clint, Tex.
item.description: “Safe and sanitary” conditions are legally required for detained migrant children. Reports from a Texas border station set off an outcry that those standards weren’t being met.
item.media:description: Lawyers who visited a border station in Clint, Tex., last month reported filthy and negligent conditions for the young migrants who were detained there.

item.title: ‘Your Heritage Is Taken Away’: The Closing of 3 Historically Black Colleges
item.description: For nearly 200 years, historically black colleges and universities have educated thousands of students, but they continue to face an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: Wadzanai Mhute
item.media:credit: Jeremy M. Lange for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main quad of Bennett College.

item.title: San Francisco Banned Facial Recognition. Will California Follow?
item.description: Monday: A debate about tech, surveillance and privacy. Also: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s first budget; and cheers to Negronis.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan

item.title: Do the Republicans Even Believe in Democracy Anymore?
item.description: They pay lip service to it, but they actively try to undermine its institutions.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tomasky

item.title: Please Stop Telling Me America is Great
item.description: Politicians love to say it’s the greatest, but the numbers (and reality) don’t back them up.
item.dc:creator: Taige Jensen and Nayeema Raza
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

item.title: The Trump-Kim Meeting Was Great TV. It Was Also Something Much More Important.
item.description: With his visit to the Demilitarized Zone, the president is opening the door for real negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Joel S. Wit
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump met with Kim Jong-un, leader of North Korea, in the Korean Peninsula’s Demilitarized Zone, on Sunday.

item.title: Iran Is Rushing to Build a Nuclear Weapon — and Trump Can’t Stop It
item.description: The White House strategy of “maximum pressure” is backfiring in the most dangerous way possible.
item.dc:creator: John J. Mearsheimer

item.title: How to Defy the Catholic Church
item.description: Believers have a spiritual obligation to defend their L.G.B.T.Q. brothers and sisters, even against archbishops.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Who Should Live in Flooded Old New York?
item.description: Residents of the drowned city remain illegally, and have nowhere else to go.
item.dc:creator: Brooke Bolander

item.title: A Hong Kong Protester’s Tactic: Get the Police to Hit You
item.description: Using aggressive nonviolence to provoke the authorities and win over the public.
item.dc:creator: Fred Chan Ho-fai

item.title: What if All Your Slack Chats Were Leaked?
item.description: Unless the company makes changes to its encryption and retention policies, using Slack could put your data at risk.
item.dc:creator: Gennie Gebhart

item.title: The Trump Fallacy
item.description: Despite what some of the president’s supporters think, you cannot celebrate his policies and ignore his poor behavior.
item.dc:creator: Greg Weiner

item.title: Why Can’t Pakistan Afford to Ban Indian Movies?
item.description: Despite efforts to introduce movies from other cultures, Bollywood remains the primary choice for the country’s moviegoers.
item.dc:creator: Mazhar Zaidi
item.media:description: A torn movie poster outside a theater in Lahore, Pakistan.

item.title: Trump’s Iran Strategy Will Fail. Here’s Why.
item.description: ‘Maximum pressure’ will only strengthen the Revolutionary Guards, which has recast itself as the defender of a new, nationalist narrative.
item.dc:creator: Narges Bajoghli

item.title: N.B.A. Free Agency Updates: Signings, Trades and More
item.description: Kevin Durant. Kyrie Irving. Jimmy Butler. But no Kawhi Leonard (so far). Dozens of deals have been reported, and the chaos has only just begun.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola, Sopan Deb and Marc Stein
item.media:description: Kevin Durant before Game 5 of the NBA Finals last month.

item.title: ‘Three Women’ Takes a Long, Close Look at Sex Lives
item.description: Lisa Taddeo spent eight years with the subjects of her book, an immersive look at a particular story of female sexuality, refracted three ways.
item.dc:creator: Parul Sehgal

item.title: Pete Buttigieg Raised $24.8 Million in Second Quarter, His Campaign Says
item.description: Mr. Buttigieg’s total is the latest evidence that he has gone from a long shot to a serious candidate for the Democratic nomination in a matter of months.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan
item.media:description: Pete Buttigieg after a Democratic presidential debate in Miami on Thursday.

item.title: Israel Is Blamed for Deadly Missile Strikes in Syria
item.description: A series of overnight attacks by warplanes hit Syrian and Iranian-affiliated targets amid escalating tensions between Washington and Tehran in the region.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A still from a video showing smoke near the Syrian capital, Damascus, after a reported Israeli airstrike.

item.title: Mexico Hailstorm Blankets Western Areas Under 3 Feet of Ice
item.description: A local mayor said he had never seen anything like it. The Mexican Army also assisted in the cleanup.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra

item.title: Lil Nas X Comes Out on Last Day of Pride Month
item.description: The 20-year-old “Old Town Road” rapper pointed to the lyrics of “c7osure,” a song off his new EP, as confirmation of his sexuality.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Lil Nas X performing “Old Town Road” at the BET awards last week. The rapper’s coming out on social media feels fitting, as he built his fame as an amateur meme maker.

item.title: La Scala Opera Chooses New Leader
item.description: Dominique Meyer, the head of the Vienna State Opera, will take over at the storied Italian institution in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Under Modi, Hindus Find Hope for a Temple on Disputed Speck of Land
item.description: Hindus and Muslims have long sparred over a few barren acres in the city of Ayodhya. But since Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s commanding election win, Hindus feel a new optimism.
item.dc:creator: Kai Schultz and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A model of a proposed Hindu temple draws visitors in Ayodhya, India. Since elections in May, Hindus have become increasingly confident that the temple will be built on a disputed site.

item.title: Poachers Are Invading Botswana, Last Refuge of African Elephants
item.description: New data leave little doubt that the illegal ivory trade has reached the country, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.media:description: Elephants in Chobe National Park in northern Botswana.

item.title: Wounded by Chemical Weapons in Iraq, Veterans Fight a Lonely Battle for Help
item.description: Annette Nellis and three other airmen came forward with health issues years after they were exposed to chemicals during a training exercise. When will the military provide the recognition they were promised?
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Matt Eich for The New York Times
item.media:description: During a mission in Iraq in 2005, Annette Nellis saw pinhead-size blisters forming on her face and chest. Within six hours, those blisters had each grown to half the size of a dime.

item.title: 2,000 Cameras Will Be Watching How You Drive in New York City
item.description: Will the nation’s largest urban network of speed cameras make the city safer or “one big speed trap?”
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu
item.media:description: A camera was installed on West End Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan as part of a major expansion of a program in New York City to discourage speeding near schools.

item.title: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Keep Your Bedroom Cool
item.description: As summer heats up, here are some ways to keep cool at home.
item.dc:creator: Christine Cyr Clisset
item.media:credit: Katherine Marks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Northwest view from bedroom in Manhattan.

item.title: Could Ancient Greek Philosophy Help You Work Smarter and Better?
item.description: The idea of “temperaments” or “humors” has been long debunked, but thinking in terms of broad personality types may actually help you get things done.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Grace Saunders

item.title: 10 Ways to Lower the Cancer Risk of Grilling
item.description: If you plan to grill often experts suggest taking some small steps to make a big difference in lowering your exposure to compounds that are tied to cancer.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Michael Graydon for The New York Times

item.title: Taylor Swift on Scooter Braun Buying Her Old Label: ‘My Worst Case Scenario’
item.description: In a Tumblr post on Sunday, the singer called out the powerful music manager for his purchase of her back catalog.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli
item.media:description: The sale “has stripped me of my life’s work,” Taylor Swift wrote Sunday. She accused Scooter Braun of “incessant, manipulative bullying.”

item.title: Serena Williams’s Coach Says She Is Pain Free. Watch Out, Wimbledon?
item.description: If she is healthy, Williams can defeat any woman on grass, even at 37. But her health has been a persistent concern.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Serena Williams, who has won Wimbledon seven times, is in the toughest quarter of this year’s draw.

item.title: The Prom Where the City Councilman Dances the Jennifer Grey Part from ‘Dirty Dancing.’ And He’s Not Bad.
item.description: Sneaking a peek at an annual dance in Brooklyn, when a local politician wore a ball gown. He looked fabulous.
item.dc:creator: John Leland and Gaia Squarci
item.media:credit: Gaia Squarci for The New York Times

item.title: Review: Hugh Jackman Isn’t Quite the Greatest Showman in an Arena
item.description: His world tour “The Man. The Music. The Show.” stopped at Madison Square Garden. But it would have been better on Broadway.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: New York City Gay Men's Chorus
item.media:description: Hugh Jackman during his arena tour concert “The Man. The Music. The Show.” at Madison Square Garden.

item.title: South Africa Meets South Asia at Peri Peri Grill House
item.description: Smoke, spice and an eclectic menu are the hallmarks of this small restaurant in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Mahira Rivers
item.category: Peri Peri Grill House (Brooklyn, NY, Restaurant)
item.media:credit: Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times

item.title: Do Hand Dryers Hurt Kids’ Hearing? This 13-Year-Old Studied It
item.description: Nora Keegan noticed that dryers tended to be closer to children’s ears. So she set out on a study that was eventually published in a medical journal in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: Nora Keegan after winning a medal at a science fair for her research on the noise levels of hand dryers.

item.title: Drugged, Castrated, Eager to Mate: the Lives of Fungi-Infected Cicadas
item.description: “This really has all the elements of a sci-fi horror story,” a mycologist said.
item.dc:creator: JoAnna Klein
item.media:description: When cicadas are infected by a parasitic fungus, the insect’s innards get digested and their rear ends are replaced by a chalky white plug of spores.

item.title: Reversing the Damage of a Stroke
item.description: For one patient, a decade of recovery took determination, persistence and the courage to weather repeated setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Jane E. Brody

item.title: Keeping the Fun in Children’s Sports
item.description: “The evidence shows that what makes sports really fun for kids is trying hard, making progress, being a good sport, experiencing positive coaching,” a doctor of sports medicine said.
item.dc:creator: Perri Klass, M.D.

item.title: Reefer Madness or Pot Paradise? The Surprising Legacy of the Place Where Legal Weed Began
item.description: Colorado’s first-in-the-nation experiment with legalized marijuana has infused the drug into almost every corner of life.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers prepared for marijuana planting on Woody Farms in Pueblo, Colo. The state’s first-in-the-nation experiment with legalizing recreational marijuana put it on the front lines of changing America’s drug laws.

item.title: For a ‘Saturday Night Live’ Writer, a Permanent Musical Guest
item.description: The Swedish rapper Rebin Shah, a.k.a. Rebstar, and Megan Callahan were married in a low-key ceremony in Tarrytown, N.Y.
item.dc:creator: Alix Strauss
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Megan Callahan and Rebin Shah surrounded by family members and friends at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Tarrytown, N.Y.

item.title: How to Host a Relaxed, Italian-Style Late Lunch
item.description: The chef Amber Guinness, who runs the Arniano Painting School from her family’s country house in Tuscany, shares her tips for easygoing entertaining.
item.dc:creator: Laura Rysman
item.media:description: The garden at Villa Arniano, the Tuscan farmhouse owned by the Guinness family, which for four weeks each year hosts the Arniano Painting School.
